Situation1: Their partner faces a tough decision at work and seeks advice and encouragement.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, my husband’s hands wrapped tightly around his coffee mug. His eyes were clouded with worry as he explained the dilemma at work—his boss had asked him to lead a project he wasn’t sure he could handle. He needed me, not just to listen, but to reassure him, to help him believe he could do it. I could see how much he was struggling, and I wanted nothing more than to stay, to offer the comfort and encouragement he deserved.

But my phone buzzed with a reminder: my volunteer shift started in twenty minutes. I was supposed to be there on time, to set an example and help with the morning setup. I knew the others could cover for me if I was late, but I also knew how much the organization relied on my reliability. My heart twisted as I glanced between my husband and the clock, feeling the weight of both roles pressing down on me. I wanted to be the supportive wife he needed, but I also didn’t want to let my fellow volunteers down. The expectations tugged at me from both sides, and I sat there, torn, unsure which part of myself to honor first.
